data.text: Fenders on Multi-Day All-Road Touring/Bikepacking?

Edit: due to overwhelming and convincing pro-fender arguments, I've decided to keep the fenders. Are you "yay" or "nay" to fenders when multi- day all-road (including gravel) touring/bikepacking? I recently fit my Kona Unit with fenders, thinking I might appreciate them on longer multi-day tours where riding in poor weather is unavoidable. Ive gotta say... just riding around town, I don't love fenders on this bike. I don't like the esthetic, how they collect debris on muddy backroads, or how gravel gets kicked up and rattles about in them (and yes, I realize that last one means they're doing their job and saving my frame from chips and scratches). But of course, I understand they'd make a wet ride less unpleasant. Just looking for other opinions, experience and perspective on using fenders.
Long tours in bad weather, it‚Äôs a no brainer.

data.text: Exactly how I use my SKS Speed Rocker fenders, just occasionally. Last gravel event I did was really sloppy & I was the only one with fenders. 1/2 way through, a buddy comes up to my side - "You're too clean" & wipes his muddy hand on my still clean jersey. "Thats better" he says. I helped another buddy back who was coated in grit, with a failed bottom bracket from it. My fenders work awesome, strap-on quickly & are not a bother the few times I use them. Bikepacking? I don't know, my packs do a good job themselves, except for my feet/bottom bracket
